p: The wild rhizome of A. amatymbica was obtained from its natural habitat in Emnyameni village (32°34′17.39 ″S; 27°6′55.16 ″E) in the Keiskammahoek area of the Eastern Cape Province, South Africa, in May 2014. The vegetation type is Amathole Montana grassland [ 21]. The cultivation of the plant was carried out in a greenhouse until flowering (May–December 2014) at Fort Cox College of Agriculture and Forestry. The rhizomes from both wild and cultivated A. amatymbica were collected at the flowering stage. Plants were authenticated at the Department of Botany in the University of Fort Hare, and voucher specimens Mau2015/04 and Mau2015/05 were deposited at the Giffen Herbarium of the university.
